2.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 février 2016
I love puzzle games like this one, and Magrunner, and the Portals. I'm 70 yrs. old and I'm trying to keep my brain sharp. But when the game designers INCLUDE a NECESSITY for DEXTERITY in the game, it really ticks me off. I get really disappointed by the fact that I paid the same price as anyone else, or close to it, but I don't get to finish the game, because my fingers aren't as fast as my brain. This game does just that. I love the whole concept of mixing the colors to open the doors, and even getting the colors in the right orders. It's a cool concept and fun to play and solve the puzzles. BUT here I am running from a fire that my fingers just aren't fast enough to solve the puzzle. Although I know WHAT to do, I can't physically do it. Maybe I could if I did it over and over and over a million times, but I don't care to do that, that's why I bought a PUZZLE game. Maybe I should have waited a while to cool down before I wrote this. I recommend this game for anyone that loves puzzles, AND has the DEXTERITY to solve them!
 
adamfirstone
13
73 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
6 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
1
Non recommandé
4.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 mars 2018
It tries to be Portal and fails. The great thing about Portal is that it's next to impossible to get stuck: sure you can die, but given portals are temporary and destroyed items respawn, there's rarely anything you can't undo. Not so in Chromagun. Once you paint something, you can't unpaint it. Paint something red, the best you can do is make it purple or orange, you will never be able to make it blue or yellow. And that means that it's very easy to make a mistake you can't come back from, and frankly that spoils things. The puzzles we enjoy, if you make a mistake you can undo it, be that by overwriting it in pen, or jumping back through that portal.

Long story short: tries to be Portal, acknowledges it's trying to be Portal, fails miserably at being Portal.

Seriously, why didn't they provide a paint stripper function on this gun?
 
TheNewNo2
0
43 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
10.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 28 avril 2016
I nearly didn't buy ChromaGun because I read in another review that the difficulty spiked and the game went from gentle puzzling to demanding serious dexterity. I'm glad I chose to try it anyway. For context, let me explain that I am an average gamer in my early-fifties with serious sight issues, and yet I completed the game in around 10 hours with 100% achievements. The puzzles ranged from easy to mildly challenging. The basic mechanic of manipulating droids by changing their colour, or the colour of their surroundings, is a neat one. The devs have borrowed Portal's premise of a guy (or gal) going through test chambers. Critics might say this is unoriginal and I suppose they have a point, but at least it's better than the cheesy 'contestant in a deadly game show' format utilised by several of the other games in this genre. It also means Chromagun's levels are bite-size - some of them take a few seconds to complete once you're figured the solution - so if you screw up it's no hardship to restart and try again. This makes it a good game to boot up whether you have ten minutes to kill or wish to spend a few hours gaming.

To sum up, ChromaGun isn't an ambitious game. The graphics and sound are solid and unpretentious, it's slick and bug-free, and there's a welcome side serving of humour in the voice over. Recommend. 8/10
 
Inspiral
4,967 produits enregistrés
1
62 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation amusante
0
Recommandé
6.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 février 2016
Chromagun is billed as a first-person action puzzle game, although it starts off focusing mostly on the puzzle aspect and then picks up the pace later on. If you're after a thoughtful, no-pressure game then you'll struggle later on where speed is important.

It's inspired by Portal, with a similar look and narration, but the puzzle mechanic is totally different. Here, it's about painting walls and droids different colours with your paint gun. Droids get pulled towards any surface that's the same colour as them, so you use that fact to move them around the level and position them on pressure pads that open doors.

To add some action, some droids are deadly to the touch and will chase you around the level if there's no coloured surface to pull them in.

Some gameplay from chapter 2, post-tutorial:
Vidéo YouTube™: Chromagun gameplay is Portal meets Splatoon! [PC let's play/review playtest] 
Vues : 2,286
See how to escape the evil Chromagun testing facility armed only with a paint gun in this let's play Chromagun gameplay review.


The paint-mixing idea is a great basis for setting puzzles, but it feels like they could have done more than just using it to get droids to cling to walls. Particularly because (based on what I've played so far, 3/4 of the way through the game) this is a 3D game that never really uses the third dimension in your puzzle solving.

Like all decent puzzle games, the game intelligently drip-feeds in new elements and teaches you their use, either through direct explanation or letting you discover it for yourself. Chapter 1 is a tutorial with one colour in your gun, Chapter 2 gives you the full three-colour gun and teaches you the art of mixing, while chapter 3 adds killer floor tiles that destroy droids, sometimes to your advantage. Chapter 4 adds walls that remove your paint after a short time. And so on, up to Chapter 8.

But this is a game with a story, and Chapter 4 ends on an action-packed climax ready for an atmospheric Chapter 5. At this point you wonder if the game up to this point was one long tutorial! Beyond this, the puzzles require faster thinking, faster timing and all-round more speed to proceed.

A few puzzles are inelegantly designed, ones that makes you wonder if you found an unintended shortcut or whether the rooms needed a second draft.

For instance, level 4.5 was first one where I was stumped for a while - the solution turned out to be mentally putting together stuff I'd done before, but it also required getting a droid to pass a certain point at a certain time that was annoyingly fiddly - I had already figured things out but spent ages running in circles to get it just right. I couldn't work out if it was me or the game at fault.

But all the puzzles are contained enough to be manageable. It rarely puts a second difficult puzzle after a first within a level (which might mean if you die on the second you'd have to plod all the way through the first again).

So I've been enjoying this, with reservations. I found the early stuff a bit gentle and I rattled through a lot of the game before hitting the real challenge, but it always changed things up before becoming boring. I enjoy the moments of panic and quick-thinking, and solving a puzzle is satisfying. But some of the timing later on is too tight to be fun and gets frustrating. But never mouse-breakingly so!

* More gaming videos by Randomise User
 
RandomiseUser

Recommandé
8.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 23 aout 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

Игра ChromaGun является головоломкой с видом от первого лица.
Сюжет прост. Используя оружие стреляющее цветными зарядами, которые окрашивают стены и/или дроидов, пробиться к выходу на следующий этаж. В игре 8 глав по 5-9 этажей. Начинается игра с очень простых заданий, которые постепенно усложняются. Затем наступает момент, когда необходимо серьезно включать мозг. Любое неверное действие приводит к невозможности прохождения этажа и требуется рестарт.
Потом наступает черед ловкости рук и быстроты клика, и вновь мозговой штурм, и рестарты, рестарты… Уровни сделаны интересно. Игра реально захватывает. Дошедших до конца игры ждет небольшой сюрприз от разработчика. Рекомендую всем любителям данного жанра. Игра привлекает невысокой ценой.
Для тех у кого возникли сложности при прохождении или желает ознакомится с геймплеем игры можно посмотреть видео (полное прохождение из 7 частей) на Steam:

ChromaGun: Chapter 1-2 / Главы 1-2 
Une vidéo de ChromaGun
Par : LapoT
Добро пожаловать в лабораторию Хромотек! Ты здесь для того, чтобы протестировать новую военную технологию подбора красок: Хроморужье. В данном видео прохождение первой и второй главы.

Добро пожаловать в лабораторию Хромотек! Ты здесь для того, чтобы протестировать новую военную технологию подбора красок: Хроморужье. В данном видео прохождение первой и второй главы.


Ключ был предоставлен разработчиком игры.

Recommandé
4.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 aout 2019
Produit reçu gratuitement

Давайте раскрасим этот скучный мир!

И пусть лаборатория Aperture нам завидует!

Добро пожаловать, Испытуемый.

Правда ли младший брат GLaDOS?
Механика игры на первый взгляд напоминает Portal, основоположницу игр такого жанра. Всё, что нам необходимо делать - заставлять шарики определённого цвета притягиваться к кнопке, которая выпустит нас из комнаты. Интерьер подозрительно напоминает психиатрическую больницу, но, с другой стороны, если бы стены были не белыми, как бы мы их раскрашивали? /капитан очевидность снова с вами!/
И всё же до любимого Портала она, конечно, не дотягивает. Не хватает сюжета, очаровательных персонажей, атмосферности, какой-то изюминки.

Смотрите, он делает свой первый прыжок!
Ну, или только пытается. Да кого это вообще волнует? - примерно таков дух речей, произносимых невидимым наблюдателем. Вы можете остаться в начале уровня, не поставив игру на паузу, отойти за вкусняшками, а вернуться к компьютеру под аккомпанемент гневных речей наблюдателя, перемежающихся советами "для особо умных", из разряда (вольный пересказ):
Ну, давай, попробуй найти выход. Это дверь, над которой написано ВЫХОД. В, Ы, Х, О, Д. У тебя получится!
Чем-то напоминает язвительные комментарии GLaDOS, но теряется очарование ИИ, потому что наш наблюдатель - живой человек, и его комментарии лично мне больше напомнили Stanely Parable.

Общее впечатление
Интересная игра на один раз. Сюжет проходить вновь особого желания нет, т.к. и история там почти отсутствует, только набор фраз наблюдающего за нами человека. Вас будут ожидать разнообразные задачи, но второй раз их будет не так интересно решать, поэтому хороший выход - наличие камер от сообщества.
Местами приходится ломать голову, местами - ловкость пальцев и никакого мошенничества, но в целом игра мне понравилась и отлично зашла на пару вечеров. Само прохождение не займёт много времени: от 2,5 до 3,5 часов + ещё некоторое время на выбивание последней ачивки. поджарь их всех!

Плюсы:
+ интересные головоломки;
+ хорошая оптимизация;
+ наличие испытаний от игроков;
+ относительно легко выбиваются все достижения, кроме одного;
+ есть режим для спидранеров (зачем он там?);
+ возможность сыграть в демку.

Минусы:
- нельзя удалить цвет при ошибке;
- это не Portal xD

Итог: если вы ищете себе хорошее развлечение на пару вечеров, то советую не проходить мимо данной игры. Если сомневаетесь, попробуйте демо-версию.

Кому понравится: любителям поломать голову за чашкой чая /кофеи поклонникам Portal, Quantum Conundrum и прочих 3D-головоломок.
 
ethersy

The game is overshadowed by Portal, but with one key difference. In most parts of portal if you get a portal not just right you can iterate, fix, learn. With this game if you paint something, it's a done deal. You have to restart the level, which sometimes is very tedious. This game would work great as a top-down phone game.

Évaluation publiée le 24 juillet 2018
After reading various reviews on it, I decided to take a gamble on this game and just buy it since it was on sale. I've played it for about 40 minutes now and I just simply am not having a good time. The puzzles aren't hard. The game just doesn't seem fun. If you mispaint a wall, you have to start the entire level over. You can't repaint the wall white to start fresh. That simple mechanic about the game ruins the entire experience in my opinion. I feel like i'm not playing a puzzle game, but a narrow learn-by-mistake walking simulator masquerading as a puzzle game. Whoever buys this game, I hope they enjoy it. I wanted to believe in this game, but I just can't find myself to

Recommandé
17.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 aout 2023
Весьма и весьма неплохая головоломка с видом от первого лица, напоминающая "Portal". Только вместо портальной пушки у вас в руках пушка, стреляющая цветными шарами. Сюжета особо нет. Принцип геймплея такой же как и в "Portal". Преодолеть ряд комнат, решая головоломки. Только игровая механика разительно отличается и имеет свой шарм. Используя пушку, стреляющую цветными шариками (красный, синий и жёлтый), нужно окрашивать участки стен и летающие дроиды, чтобы окрашенный дроид притянулся к кнопке соответствующего цвета, которая откроет препятствие или выход из комнаты. Сначала задания не представляют особой сложности, но дальше этапы заметно усложняются. Цвета нужно совмещать, создавая другой цвет, появляются всевозможные препятствия и силовые поля, появляются дроиды, убивающие вас, а некоторые участки стен и дроиды не подвергаются окрашиванию и т.д. А на некоторых этапах нужно не только применять мозговой штурм, но и использовать всю ловкость ваших рук.
В общем, игра хорошая. До Портала не дотягивает конечно, но свою привлекательность имеет. Геймплей интересен, интуитивно понятен и увлекателен. Имеются коллекционные карточки и достижения. Последние не так просто сделать, если не подглядывать в гайды.
 
Каспер666

Évaluation publiée le 17 février 2018
Produit remboursé

Meh...

People are comparing this game to portal for a good reason: it tries really hard to imitate portal in all the dimensions, but fails everywhere:
- most importantly, puzzles are not challenging at all (took me ~2 hours to finish it)
- story is essentially non-existent - you hear the narrator maybe on 5-6 occasions throughout the whole game - and the jokes are blantly stupid (the "ironical" component of them usually goes like "we thought you were a complete idiot, but it seems that the 'complete' part was incorrect" - btw, just wrote this and realized that this is better than all the 'jokes' in the game)

Non recommandé
15.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 20 mars 2018
This is a mediocre game, at best.

People keep comparing it to Portal (when I say this, I mainly mean Portal 2), but I don't think they can be at all reasonably compared. Portal is lightyears ahead in quality: it's several years older, yet it's much more innovative, better scripted, better acted, looks better, has far better interface responsiveness, and probably a lot more I'm not mentioning here. I cannot think of a single way in which Portal doesn't blow this game out of the water.

Whereas the humor in Portal was hilarious and witty, ChromaGun's sarcastic narration misses the mark by a mile, largely being comprised of a somewhat obnoxious barrage of reused insults directed toward the player.

Probably the most annoying thing about ChromaGun, though, is how laggy its responsiveness is to inputs. It was borderline unplayable for me, using an older machine. (It's a laptop and still substantially exceeds all *Recommended* system requirements, except graphics---which are not exactly complex.) A couple of levels (one in particular) were speed-based, too, and this lag "feature" made them nearly impossible to complete, even though I knew exactly what I needed to do. (Portal, on the other hand, has sharp, crisp responsiveness... while still managing to look better, too!) There's just no excuse for this.

ChromaGun also had relatively little progressive innovation in it. It was mostly just pushing buttons via a bunch of painting things different colors; the end. Yeah, it introduced some minor variations on this, like "paint splashers", "paint erasers", a tiny bit of floor painting, and some eletrified tiles, but those aren't exactly wildly creative. (Portal had portals, but also had buttons, multiple types of portable cubes/orbs, energy fields, gravity wells, light bridges, several different gels that did totally different things, lasers, turrets, elevators, ... basically, a lot of innovation all over the place.)

In the end, just finishing the game turned into something of a chore that I forced myself to do.

I think the ChromaGun concept may have potential, and certainly some parts of it were decent. But, overall, I think it just wasn't executed very well. (I think Q.U.B.E. is better than ChromaGun, too.) ChromaGun is not a game to get all excited about, and It's basically a toss-up on whether or not to recommend it as merely a way to pass some time here and there, but I think ultimately... I have to go with No.
 
Ninsar
1
8 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
1 personne a trouvé cette évaluation amusante

Recommandé
2.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 octobre 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

🎮ChromaGun🎮
Indie Puzzle Spiel aus deutscher Hand

Die Vorgeschichte
Herzliche Willkommen in der Teststation von ChromaTec! Du bist unser auserwählter Exklusiv Tester der neuesten Erfindung „Chroma Gun“. Eine Farbpistole des Farbmilitärs.

Das Spiel
„ChromaGun“ ist ein Rätsel Puzzle Spiel des deutschen Indie Entwicklers Pixel Maniacs. Fans von Spielen wie Portal werden sich rasch Willkommen fühlen. Man läuft mit einer Farbpistole durch verschiedene Räume und muss durch verstellen der Farben Rätsel lösen, Roboter ablenken oder an bestimmte Stellen locken. Zu Beginn sind die Farbrätsel noch keine große Herausforderung, von Raum zu Raum werden die Rätsel kniffliger. Trotz wenig Erfahrung mit Puzzle Spielen fand ich mich rasch zurecht und kam gut voran. Manchmal kamen mir jedoch Räume leichter vor als die Räume zuvor. Ich weiß nicht ob die Schwierigkeit spielbedingt schwankt oder ob ich mich an die Rätsel einfach gewöhnt habe…

Die Grafik des Spiels hat mich für das Ergebnis eines Indie Studios überzeugt, ich kann da echt nicht meckern! Wie auch bei Portal gibt es im Spiel einen „Sprecher“. Gelegentlich triggerte mich sein Gelaber. Ich unterstelle den Entwicklern einfach mal, dass das auch so gewollt ist ;). Die Musik unterstützt das Spielerlebnis und sorgt für gute Stimmung, selbst an Stellen wo man mal ein wenig feststeckt.

Positiv
+ tolle Grafik
+ nette Puzzle Rätsel
+ tolle Musik
+ man findet rasch ins Spiel

Negativ
- gefühlt keine lineare Steigerung der Schwierigkeit
- häufige kurze Ladescreens egal wie kurz der Raum war

Fazit
Nettes Puzzle Spiel aus einem deutschen Indie Entwicklerstudio. Portal und Co. Schon durch? Schaut mal rein!
★★★★★ ★☆☆☆☆ 6/10 Sterne

Folge HeikarGaming & Friends um weitere Reviews von mir zu entdecken

Évaluation publiée le 20 janvier 2018
Когда ленивен, но хочется денег.
Обрисую ситуацию. Новая механика, не замудрённая, даже очень простая, можно придумать море интересного. Уровни очень простые, потратил 3 часа на игру. И то, часть времени убил на открытие скрытых достижений. Извините, но надо быть отсталым, чтобы потратить 5+ часов на эту игру (не считая карты сообщества, которые ещё не опробовал) и кричать, что игра сложная... Не удивлюсь, если найдутся спидранеры за 1 час, а то и меньше. Атмосфера скатана с портала. То есть белоснежные камеры с яркими вкраплениями, аналог Кейва Джонсона, музыка даже по стилю напоминает. Можете кидать тухлые помидоры, но это далеко не самый оригинальный проект, а так, проходняк...

Évaluation publiée le 22 juin 2016
The game has the same feel of portal with a different type of puzzle. That being said, I did have fun. However part of me feels like portal inspired this game, because it was way too similar with the announcer and the white tiles and the gun, ect. Some of the puzzles were not so clear at first and I found my own way to complete them. I wish this game was either longer or had better puzzles. The tedious, run for your life missions, got kind of annoying after a while but it was fine.

buy this game if you miss portal or like puzzle games in general.

1.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 12 septembre 2016
Chromagun é um jogo estilo portal em que você tem que usa combinação de cores para passar pelos desafios. Jogo é interessante e em alguma promoção na Steam vale a pena ser adquirido. Caso queira ver como é o jogo vou deixar um vídeo de gameplay que fiz.

Vidéo YouTube™:

Évaluation publiée le 19 juin 2020
People have already pointed out the issues:
1) It's way too easy to make a silly mistake and you have to redo the entire level from the beginning
2) Frame rate stutters that are more annoying than problematic, but it breaks whatever small amount of flow you manage to achieve.

number 2 I could live with but number 1 is inexcusable.

All they need is a white paint option on right click. Or an Undo/rewind time but white paint would probably be easier to implement. Or just have it so that instead of turning black, the third colour just starts the cycle again... or the fourth colour after black... I mean, there are 4 ideas of possible ways to fix the glaring gameplay problem.

I doubt the devs will do it.

Évaluation publiée le 8 mai 2019
Note that this review has Thumbs up only because ~meh~ is not an option on steam.

This game is in dire need of either Quicksave or a way to decolor already colored things. Especially the later levels have stages where you have to do preceise shots with correct timing (which is not helped by your character walking slow as s***) so if during any of this you shoot 1 pxel too much to the left or dare to shoot with the wrong color then you can redo the entire puzzle.

This is especially bad because the puzzles often are not clear from the start. You have to let yourself trapped or have to do leaps of faith just to progress. And when it then turned out that actually you needed another color on a robot than you used then guess what: restart.

Also this game wants to be portal way too much (they even have a cake). The announcer is annoying and doesn't even talk at start of each level but has long stretches of gameplay where he doesn't say anything (which honestly are the better ones).

The worst part of all of this is that the core of the game is really good. All it needs are some quality lof life improvements, some better graphics (I mean look at the hand, just look at it!) and another voice actor and this game could be great.

But it's meh.

Recommandé
6.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 juillet 2016
Chromagun is a first person puzzler game similar to many such games available on Steam like Portal series, Magnetic: Cage close, Q.U.B.E, etc. You have a paint gun which you have to shoot at droids and walls and combining these two actions you’ll have to trigger switches which open doors to the next level.

Graphics:

The graphics are run of the mill average. Nothing too fancy, the levels are mostly white with little color. This makes sense because the whole game is about coloring the wall panels and the puzzles are based on coloring them correctly, so a white background is the ideal in this case. There aren’t too many graphics options in the game. The game is locked at 60 FPS but I noticed no slowdowns or dips in FPS. The game also features colorblind mode so that’s always a positive.

Sound:

The game has very slow and relaxing music. The sound effects can be a bit annoying though. The narration is very well done in this game. I was quite impressed with the narrator. It has funny humor as narration just like Portal.

Gameplay:

Your main Chromagun can shoot paint in 3 colors, yellow, blue and red. You can combine these colors to make purple, green and orange i.e. yellow and red will make orange etc. You have to go through bunch of tests and unlock doors to open new levels. To open doors there are switches in each level. There can be more than one switch and more than one door as well. The switches correspond to their respective doors and this is represented by a wire on the ground which is color coded. So if you see a purple wire going out from a switch you just follow it and it’ll tell you which door this switch will open.

To activate switches you have to get these droids to move on top of them. You can paint the droids and certain types of wall panels. The droid will be attracted to the same colored wall panel and if there are 2 or more of the same color wall panels, the droid will stay in the middle of these. E.G if there are 5 panels of blue colors right next to each other, the blue painted droid will go to the wall and stand in front of the 3rd blue wall panel. If the number is even, the droid will stay in-between the 3rd and 4th panel.

There are 2 types of droids, normal ones and spiked ones. The normal ones don’t move unless you paint a wall near them with the same color they are. The spiked ones however, once you paint them, they get triggered and they follow you around and hurt you and eventually kill you. This can be stopped by luring them next to the wall that is same color as these droids. So, you have to make use of this to solve puzzles.

A short gameplay video can be found below:

Chromagun short gameplay[60FPS] 
Une vidéo de ChromaGun
Par : Thugnificent


Graphics:6/10
Sound:7/10
Gameplay:7/10
Overall:7/10

Conclusion:

If you’re into first person puzzle games similar to Portal, Q.U.B.E, Magnetic: Cage closed etc. then this game is right up your alley. It’s got enough content for its price and in my opinion and should keep you entertained for 4-5 hours easily. If you think that’s not enough you can always wait for the next big sale and pick it up. The game has some awesome narration as well which can be entertaining.
 
Thugnificent

Recommandé
6.8 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 novembre 2019
Produit reçu gratuitement

For more puzzle game reviews, news and everything puzzle-related, follow Puzzle Lovers and check out our Steam group.

chromagun is a competent 1st-person puzzler where you mix colors to paint surfaces and droids to move them out of the way, open doors, etc. the presentation is very good, I liked the music and the narrator a lot. settings are okay, separate volume sliders, rebindable keys, etc. no fov or brightness sliders though, and not much to tweak the graphics with, but it runs well even on an old system. the 8 chapters with 58 levels should take maybe 5 or 6 hours.

what makes it only a cautious recommendation is basically the lack of the local equivalent of undo, coupled with no checkpoints or saving and a lot of timing elements, as these can turn a fun game into a chore of replaying sections to get to where you dared to make a mistake. each chapter has 6-9 levels, but your progress is only saved between them, though levels are relatively short, so a few restarts may or may not cause too much of an annoyance.

the game works like this (there are of course more complex situations later): paint a wall red, paint a droid red, droid goes to wall, so you can open the door it was blocking, or the droid will activate a pressure plate this way, so you can pass through the door yourself. you have red, yellow and blue, and can mix them to create further colors as necessary. if said surface (or droid) runs out of mixable colors, it turns black and nothing else can be done with it any more, and you might have to restart the level as well.

droids are mostly harmless initially, touching them is fine too, but once they're aggroed (either by default or after getting shot), they'll go after surfaces matching their own color, and if you're nearby, you as well, though walls within reach take priority.

there's no timer as such, except for a few hurry-up sections (and unless you're playing speedrun mode), so you can take your time to figure out what to do in most cases, but there's still a lot of timing involved, running around, being chased by droids out to get you until you can attach them to a wall, in a way that still lets you finish the level, not just save your own skin. there's no health bar, but you die after a few hits.

ideally, the game would drop a checkpoint after every room, or let you quicksave anytime, or maybe have an easy mode for this and normal mode for how the game works now. it wouldn't make the puzzles easier, just cut down on unnecessary tedium, repetition and frustration, and would add the fun of experimentation without having to re-do half the level again, no matter how short they are for the most part. and the new mechanic in chapter 8 could've used a better introduction than the first level there.

if you're jonesing for a 1st-person puzzler, there's a demo with the first 10 levels, that should give you some idea of what the game is like. it's certainly not bad, there are some clever puzzles, and if you're not bothered by the stuff I mentioned above, give it a shot. otherwise maybe think twice about it, though after I got over my initial frustration and familiarized myself with the mechanics, I enjoyed it more, except the actual against-the-clock sections, and if I can complete a game like this, anybody can.
 
Dohi64
1,054 produits enregistrés
0
5 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Non recommandé
1.6 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 29 aout 2020
正直内容は面白いんだ、内容は。
もう精神的にやってられなくなったので全体の半分程度しかやってませんがレビューしておきます。
ゲーム概要
壁やオブジェクトに色が塗れるペイントガンでオブジェクトを誘導してゴールにたどり着こうというシンプルなゲーム。
オブジェクトは同じ色の壁を見つけたらそこに向かうという性質を持っており、それを使ってスイッチを押させたり地面のとげを排除させたり...とシンプルながらも考えさせてくれます。
また、青+黄色で緑、赤+青で紫などのように色の合成システムがあるのも特徴です。
一回塗ったものは基本的に白に戻せないので、どこを塗ってどこを残して別のオブジェクトを誘導するのか、なかなか奥深い感じです。
ユーザーがステージも作れるので後述する内容が苦でなければある程度楽しめるかと。
このゲームの悪い点
ここまでべた褒めしたうえで自分がこのゲームをお勧めしない唯一の理由、それが
一度でもミスをしたら最初からやり直し
という点です。
上にも書いた通り、プレイヤーが色を消す手段はありません。なので一回でも塗り方をミスしたりすればもうステージがクリアできなくなってしまうことが多々あり、そのミスを取り消す方法が存在しないため、ステージの最初からやり直しになってしまうのです。
これの何が苦痛って解き方がわかっていてもミスしたところまで戻るのが地味に長い。（ほとんどオブジェクトの動き待ち）
ゴール直前でミスろうものなら２分半くらいがそこまでの巻き戻し作業になります。わかりきった動きをしているときの虚無感はかなりのものです。
自分のプレイ時間の三分の一くらいは巻き戻し作業の時間です。
この悪い点を見てその程度か、と思った方は多分このゲーム向いてます。ぜひ面白いのでやってみてください。
そうでない方もセール中ならやる価値はあると思います。実際面白いので。
 
Pulse+

Évaluation publiée le 6 mars 2018
We were loving this game with its all-thinking-no-running puzzles until, after three hours of play (meaning, no returns allowed anymore) we suddenly hit a level where you must hustle-hustle-hustle or die. And that means die, a lot. And that means starting the level over again. A lot.

Suddenly changing from thinking to running stinks.

We'll have to find a video walkthrough and "solve" it that way, but it stinks to have to do that. This was a fun game.

Until it wasn't.

UPDATE: Okay, we got frustrated and resorted to a walkthrough, what we learned was you survive the level by simply dying and letting the game go on, which resurrects you for no reason. While that got us past the problem, and we did play the rest of the game, it felt cheap and kind of mean, so we are still not recommending this game.

9.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 novembre 2017
Of course I have to use the 'P'-word to describe this game. Test chambers, announcer guide narrator, things placed in a spot to open an exit, gun-tool that does stuff. If you need a break from the thousands and thousands of Portal levels out there but still want to run around and open up doors, definitely give ChromaGun a shot.

The premise is simple: Like-colors attract like-colors. Spray things the same color to attract them, or off-color to let them go. Open the exit door.

I'm halfway through now, and am enjoying the game a LOT. Color coding things is starting to get tougher, where I have to plan many steps ahead, programming the wall colors to lead a color somewhere when I'm somewhere else. Love it.

If there's a negative to the game so far, it's that I wish that I could undo a move. Not re-paint a thing ... but just step back in time to undo / un-paint and proceed again from there. Working on a level for 5 minutes, then realizing that I should have done something differently is ok, but having to restart the level from scratch is a bit of a bummer. Add to that the gun ... I wish that the color pipes roatated or changed to match the color ring. I keep thinking I'm spraying yellow (on top) when my ring is blue or red. That's not a big thing, just me wishing for a neat little improvement.
 
Pro-Zak

Évaluation publiée le 8 septembre 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

ChromaGun is an entertaining puzzle game that has fluid controls, great music and Portal style looks and humour.

I enjoyed the overall feel of the game and the tutorial was very much part of the gameplay which didn't interrupt your flow. I found myself saying, 'Just one more level', constantly and managed to unlock many achievements. (Not all great or encouraging ones, but certainly funny ones.) I played this for a video and had a great giggle doing so.

While some puzzles are challenging and there is certainly a gradual increase in difficulty as you would expect. I found it to be a little too gradual for myself and was left wanting for levels offering greater challenge.

That said I will play it again, I want more achievements and I did have genuine fun playing it.

Happy Gaming Peeps!

Non recommandé
4.5 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 15 juillet 2018
While i did find some enjoyment here, and it managed to be a playable 'Portal-like' for the 4.5 hrs it took me to complete the game, I feel the need to leave a negative review to point out some truly frustrating design choices that prevent me from recommending the game. Considering the game's overall rating is 'very positive' at the time that I write this, I hope this won't hurt the developers, but will hopefully provide useful feedback and warn off certain buyers who might be bothered by things that bothered me.

The game commits a very common sin amongst indie puzzle games: it admits that its core concept is not interesting enough to carry you through a full game. Or, at least, that it's developers are not confident enough to let it do so. It does this by introducing skill based barriers, such as 'puzzles' that require lightning quick speed and accuracy, a math puzzle, plain old fashioned mazes, and poorly balanced 'reflecting' puzzles requiring you to hunt for the perfect pixel to stand on to before firing at reflectors.

These kinds of puzzles are not the reason anyone is buying the game. There are hundreds of games that do those kinds of things, but better. No, the reason that people are buying this game is for puzzles about colour and line-of-sight presented in popular 'Portal-like' format, as advertised in the game's trailer. THAT is the game's core concept, and I enjoyed it when that was what I was presented with.

Unfortunately, the lightning reflex puzzles mean I cant confidently recommend this to slower paced casual gamers, or gamers with disabilities affecting input speed. The more pointless time wasting puzzles make me hesitant to recommend this to anyone who values their time. The finicky puzzles that can only be solved by standing at an extremely specific point lead me to recommend against the game unless you are a very patient completionist.

For people who are desperate to fill the hole that Portal left in your hearts, feel free to ignore my criticism and give the game a shot. There is still enjoyment to be found here, even if you don't finish the game, and the game is not that expensive. But if you are looking for a well polished game with no padding, consider looking elsewhere.

I feel like a strict editor could have turned this into an excellent 2-3 hr game instead of the frustrating and inconsistend 4-5 hr game that it ended up being. There are some great colour/line-of-sight puzzles in the game, they are just occasionally buried under frustrating barriers that don't feel like they belong here.

I felt the same about the first QUBE game, but I think the developers learned from their mistakes and made a much more consistent and memorable game in QUBE 2. I hope that one day 'ChromaGun 2' comes along and knocks my socks off in a similar fashion.
 
Racketmensch
1,005 produits enregistrés

Évaluation publiée le 5 aout 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

A First Person Adventure Puzzle Game
Vidéo YouTube™: ChromaGun || First Person Adventure Puzzle Game 
Vues : 54
#ChromaGun http://store.steampowered.com/app/408650/ Add me on Steam: http://steamcommunity.com/id/desolater_iv/ Add me on Twitter: https://twitter.com/DESOLATER_IV

+ Many similarities to Portal. You are in a test lab as a random participant chosen to test some new military grade color morphing gun.
+ A pretty comical narrator talking through intercom (I think) who watches and follows you throughout the game through various cameras and makes fun of you from time to time.
+ The gameplay is pretty fun and unique. You mainly go through a series of rooms which each have a puzzle to solve. The main mechanic involves painting hovering balls or "droids" and then painting a wall the same color which will attract the droid to the wall...generally to press a switch to open a door of some sort. Later you being to combine colors in every increasingly difficult puzzle challenges.
+ Visually the game very nice with a very clean test-lab asethetic.
+ The puzzles gradually increase in difficulty and can be quite challenging to solve....just be sure to bring a color wheel if you've never taken an art class ;)

- I wish the narrator was "more involved". I wish he would have spoke more often, and it would have been nice if he provided some hints when you got stuck. He's honestly the most charming part about the game, and really helps push the player forward although he's a bit absent through many parts.
- The environment / puzzles got a bit repetitive for me after a short while. It felt like a never-ending labryinth, and I kept asking myself "will I ever get out of here?" It really needed some more events to change up the pace and scenery.
 
GamingTaylor

Anfangs ist echt noch recht einfach und gut für einsteiger, jedoch merkt man später ein ansteigen des Schwirigkeitsgrades.

Von mir bekommt das Spiel einen Daumen nach oben. Es ist definitiv eine Empfehlung an Knobelfreunde :)

Recommandé
3.2 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 février 2022
Surprisingly awesome game.

I'm glad I ignored the negative reviews and bought this anyway because they mostly boil down to these arguments:

1) This game is not as iconic or as great as Portal.
I mean, no duh? You're comparing the Valve behemoth against this indie studio. I agree the story is barebones and could be richer but damn, man, lower your expectations for a game that you snatched for $2.59. The story is rather lacking but the gameplay is polished nicely.

2) You can't unpaint walls and droids, so you can get stuck easily.
It's a valid point but having an unpaint button would break most puzzles and defeat the whole challenge. Getting stuck is not a good design choice but the game wouldn't work otherwise. I wish it simply had quicksave/quickload though.
But the real issue here is that early levels can feature 2-3 small puzzles in one go so if you screw up the last bit you have to redo the rest. This isn't a big problem on its own but it makes you worry that you'll have to restart/redo a lot more later on. You won't. Later when puzzles get more challenging they are always short and one-at-a-time, so if you do screw up and get stuck you just think "ah okay I can't do that, let's try again" and retry.
TL;DR this is not ideal but it's much less of an issue that some people claim it to be.

3) The game requires (as one reviewer said) "ridiculous reflexes".
That's a huge overexaggeration. There are indeed two chase sequences and a few levels with timed elements. For those you'll need some absolute basic FPS gaming skills to somewhat quickly aim and fire at a few walls in a row for instance. Personally I found it to be trivial in difficulty. Anyone who played counter-strike or whatever for five minutes should be able to do it as well. There's some 70 year old reviewer who couldn't get through the game so I guess there is some barrier to it? But seriously, even Portal itself is more demanding than this. You'll be fine.

Anyways, I enjoyed it quite a lot. It's one of those puzzle games that stays creative from start to end. Instead of becoming overly obscure and complex it keeps introducing new ways to interact with the game mechanics. Basically for the most part it's "here's something new and cool, figure it out" every few levels rather than "ok here's the same thing but MUCH harder". I loved that about Chromagun.

I was worried that I won't be able to handle color-mixing puzzles but it honestly wasn't nearly as bad as I thought. You just have 6 different colors (3 basic + 3 from mixing), not counting black that you get by painting something more than twice. It turns out it's not hard to wrap your head around that at all.
 
Rushin'

Évaluation publiée le 19 juin 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

So while i do recommend this game, i dont feel it is fully worth the $13 price tag it has on steam for a <3 hour game content. I would recommend you wait for it to be either on sale or gifted to you.

So, i was approached by the games developers to try out their game and give my thoughts. {{{SPOILERS AHEAD}}}

My initial reaction to the game was surprised by just how heavily it borrowed from Portal. While i understand the developers used it for inspiration i felt it was just too much similar. From the entire style of the voice over character, to the turret like drones, white featureless walls, cameras that move when shot, level transitions and fire chasing you as they destroy the facility.

The entire game just felt like someone taking portal, changing the concept but keeping the framework of the universe the same.

Then when i got to the ending of the game and realised i had only been playing for 2 and a half hours i checked the price tag on steam and was a bit disappointed that a $13 USD game wasnt even 3 hours long. By steams refund ToS people could completely buy, play, finish and then some with the game and still easily refund it, without any issue.

The AI on the droids and movement of the character also felt very clunky at times where the momentum of the character was very ice skaterish and the droids movement felt very jagged and box like.

Overall i would give the game like 6-7/10 but it just not 100% there. Wonderful concept and game so far, just feels lacking in content and originality.
 
JMEME

Recommandé
3.4 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 juillet 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

See written review below or watch it here:
Vidéo YouTube™: ChromaGun - Quick Game Review 
Vues : 601
ChromaGun is a first person puzzle game where you are a test subject that uses colours to solve your way through the ChromaTec testing chambers.

THIS IS A MIXED REVIEW! TL;DR: SKIP TO CONCLUSION!

ChromaGun is a first person puzzle game where you are a test subject that uses colours to solve your way through the ChromaTec testing chambers.

When I first started playing, I got a Portal vibe from the game, probably because of the testing facility theme, and being immediately armed with a ChromaGun, but that’s about where the similarities between the two games end. Your main objective throughout the game is to open the exit door and move on to the next room, and there isn’t much of a story.

So, you’re in this testing facility, and your gun shoots three primary colours (red, yellow, and blue), and you can also mix colours to form secondary colours orange, green, and violet. You use your ChromaGun to shoot colours onto walls, droids and sometimes on the ground, in order to attract nearby droids of the same colour. By positioning them correctly, you’ll get the doors to open.

Pros:
  • graphics are simple, but decent (similar to Q.U.B.E. with all the white-walled rooms)
  • sound effects and music are good
  • voice acting for the narrative is done well, and it's amusing at times (similar to Quantum Conundrum with far less dialog)
  • interesting puzzle mechanics with mixing colours is straightforward, but still enjoyable if you aren’t looking for too much of a challenge
  • speedrun mode available

♥♥♥♥:
  • puzzles are too easy for those looking for a challenge, which leads to the game being a bit short (some more complex levels or larger rooms where not everything was on the same floor could’ve been neat)
  • the colour brown doesn’t work to attract the brown droids, like the other colours - it seems that it’s intended, but I don’t quite understand the reasoning behind it, since there's no way to undo colours once you shoot them, so if you accidentally turn things brown you might have to restart the level (it’s not a big deal, but still a minor nuisance)
  • small annoyance with the loading screen between levels being before you even get to the door where you have to wait anyway; could also do without the special loading screen
  • some of the voice lines get repeated when you restart the level, which is fine for the most part, as long as you don’t restart too frequently

The game starts off very easy, and it gets slightly more challenging as it progresses, but only a small handful of puzzles near the very end actually made me have to stop and think about what to do. Even then though, it was more of me trying to get the droids in the just right spot by colour changing at the right time, rather than actually having to figure the puzzles out. There are some levels that are timed, where you will burn to death if you mess up, and normally, I’m not usually a big fan of timed events, but these levels easy as well, and just took a couple attempts to solve.

Conclusion:
The game took me about 3 hours to complete, and I don’t feel the need to replay it, but there is a speedrun mode available for those who are interested. The gameplay is smooth, and I did enjoy the puzzles even though most of them were pretty easy, but I would have really liked to have had some flexibility in how you can go about solving puzzles, or even just more complex level design to make the game more challenging. If you’re interested in some puzzle gameplay with simple mechanics, you will probably enjoy ChromaGun, but keep in mind that it is a short game, and easier than games like Q.U.B.E. or Portal.

If you like my reviews, please feel free to join my Steam group, and follow my curations here.
You can also view this review on my website here.[www.azralynn.com]
 
Azralynn

4.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 février 2020
ChromaGun was a lot of fun. I am pretty picky about puzzle games because I find most of the time they try to be overly complex bordering on pretentious. ChromaGun didn’t do that. I got stumped all of twice and was able to figure out how to proceed all on my own without guides or videos. The difficulty curve just felt well done as new types of puzzles are added often without any explanation, or with very little, yet they’re very intuitive and follow common sense. The humour is spot on and the person who voiced the overseer did a fantastic job. There isn’t much in the way of a story to ChromaGun but I didn’t really mind. The game has a great pace to it. Each room takes anywhere from 30 seconds to 5-10 minutes. Even if you don’t like the room you’re in it will be over pretty quickly and you’re on to the next one. I had only two major gripes with the game: one being that you couldn’t wipe colors and the other being a timed puzzle in the last level. The lack of ability to wipe away colors means that if you screw up you have to restart the room. This may not seem like a huge deal since the rooms don’t take a long amount of time to finish but it is still annoying and something that could have been avoided or fixed. As for that last level I wasn’t too angry. I hate timed missions on principle and I did have to restart the room multiple times trying to beat the clock but as I said before the inconvenience didn’t last long. The graphics are simple but well done. Most of the rooms are majority white so as to show off the colors of the paint but the droids are well done and the few bits of the game that has something to show off were good. There is good detail on fruit that is left on desks and the clothing on people for instance. The detail on peoples faces and on plants could have been better though.

I played ChromaGun on Linux. It never crashed on me at all. I didn’t notice any glitches or bugs. Alt-Tab didn’t work. It opened on the wrong monitor once but after that never did it again. The only graphics options are for resolution; motion blur; and a toggle for image effects. There is no manual save option. The game auto saves after each room is completed which works out well given the short time each room takes. I played version 2017.05.12 Build 120 of ChromaGun. It uses the Unity engine. It takes up 1104MB of disk space. During play my GPU usage was 27-66%; my VRAM usage was 797-900MB; my CPU usage was 2-21%; my RAM usage was 2.9-3.2GB and my framerate ranged from 71-126 FPS.

I recommend ChromaGun to anyone who enjoys games such as Portal. It lacks the story of Portal but the gameplay more than rises to the challenge. I finished the story mode in 4 hours and 40 minutes. I paid $13.99 CAD for the game and find that to be great value. Even $20 would have been worth it. There is a demo available that I implore people to try if you’re interested. The demo is Windows only but worked with Proton for me on Linux.

My Score: 8.5/10

My System:

AMD Ryzen 5 2600X | 16GB DDR4-3000 CL15 | MSI RX 580 8GB Gaming X | Mesa 19.3.4 | Samsung 850 Evo 250GB | Manjaro 19.0.0 | Mate 1.24 | Kernel 5.5.2-1-MANJARO
 
PublicNuisance

Évaluation publiée le 20 février 2016
Sehr guter First Person Puzzler mit interessanter Idee.

Es gibt einige Ähnlichkeiten mit Portal 2 (Testkammern, Erzähler, Kanone), auch wenn das Gameplay komplett anders und eigenständig ist. Einige Elemente wurden aber ziemlich dreist kopiert, die ich hier nicht spoilern will.

Nichtsdestotrotz, das Spiel hat seine eigene Idee und ist gut umgesetzt. Die Spielzeit im 1. Durchgang war für mich 4,5 h.
Die Puzzles sind nicht extrem schwierig, später gibt es einige schweren Puzzles, die wieder von leichten abgelöst werden.
Insgesamt leicht bis mittelschwer.

Eine ganz klare Kaufempfehlung für Puzzle- Fans und Portal 2 Fans.

Évaluation publiée le 31 décembre 2019
A well made Portal ripoff was a solid idea but this game is not well made. It misses the important point that Portal allows the player to make mistakes and continue trying without any downtime. This game however has a single solution to a puzzle that if you don't get right straight away you need to restart the whole level and re-do every step perfectly. It's completely counter to the point of a puzzle which requires the player to try things and experiment to find solutions. This game punishes you for trying to find the answer.

Évaluation publiée le 25 juillet 2016
ChromaGun erinnert nicht zufällig an Portal, hat aber durch die Farbmischung und -anziehung seine ganz eigene Rätselmechanik. Wenn man mal durchschaut hat, wie die Kugeln angezogen werden, kann man sich ohne allzu große Schwierigkeiten durch 8 Etappen rätseln. Überflüssig sind aus meiner Sicht die zwei hektischen Passagen. Wer nicht schnell genug durchkommt, darf dann halt auswendig lernen, was man wo braucht und in welche Richtung man muss. In der letzten Etappe hat mich eine eher unauffällige neue Mechanik überrascht, die vom Spiel nicht eingeführt und danach auch nicht mehr ausführlich ausgenutzt wird. Wer Portal 1 und 2 und Portal Stories: MEL (im Classic Mode!) durchhat, oder wem letzteres zu schwierig war, der darf sich auch an ChromaGun probieren und kann damit durchaus ein paar Stunden nicht zu harten Rätselspaß haben. Das Spiel lief problemlos unter Linux.

Évaluation publiée le 5 mars 2016
To preface this. It isn't going to be a review, but more of request for future content. I've completed the game and i had a blast. it was refreshing to play another portalesq game. The commentary was hillarious and the gameplay while a bit easy in the beginning ramped up to a fun and chalenging later chapters. My request is that there eventually either add dlc that adds more levels that are more difficult. Or create a map creator similar to what portal 2 had and allow the community to create maps. This would not only allow new content for players to continue playing this awesome game, but after a editor would be created it would make less work for the Devs to create new content. I sincerely hope this game recieves frequent updates becuase i love it.

Évaluation publiée le 25 aout 2020
I’ll be honest, this game is a little too short. I do like how the game feels similar to the Portal series, and that one Portal reference is thrown in as an easter egg(you know, the one cake in the ending of Portal 1 that you never got to eat). Also the game’s mechanics are nice on their own, too. Like how you can use the paint gun to color in a segment of the wall/floor, and the “worker droids,” as the game calls those floating spherical robots, are attracted towards the painted walls depending on the color your gun uses on it. Like I said, I feel as if the game is way too short as in it has too few levels and for the most part it feels kinda… bland. Of course there are some interesting parts here and there, but that’s just about it. Also I’m really not a fan of the usage of stock music in the game. I mean there are some original songs in there but they couldn’t give themselves enough time to make more? Anyway, if you wish to play this game I say go right ahead. Just… don’t get your hopes too high up.

In my opinion, this game is a 6.5/10. Not much going on, kinda boring with the atmosphere, and mostly empty/anticlimactic.
 
Mr. Catboi

Non recommandé
3.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 16 mai 2023
ChromaGun can best be described as "meh". As a lover of first person puzzle games, I went into this with moderately high expectations, and while ChromaGun isn't the worst game ever, it is overall very mediocre. I played on Steam Deck, and had no issues getting the game to run.

The gameplay premise is simple - armed with a color gun that can shoot blue, yellow, and red, you are supposed to solve puzzles by directing colored drones to switches in every room. Shoot a wall red, and a red drone will move towards it - shoot multiple walls red and the drone will go to the middle point between the walls. It is a simple premise that is very interesting at first.

There are a few problems with the puzzles though. First, they are altogether way too easy. Only a few rooms can be problematic, and that's because you are either under a timer or because there is some tight maneuvering with the drones needed. The second problem, and that exacerbates most issues I have with the game, is that there is a lack of QOL features. If you make a mistake in the room, you can't erase a color or undo things - you have to restart the entire level. With some levels relying on timing or locking you in rooms because of timed walls or switches, this means that a single mistake means you have to repeat everything you have done before.

It is baffling to me that this gun has no way to remove paint from a wall - this alone would have made many of the puzzles so much smoother; the ability to undo mistakes that every other puzzle game has is simply missing. There is also a frustrating idle pose - if you stand still for just a few seconds, like for analyzing a puzzle, the protagonist raises the gun for an inspection, which blocks half the screen for a few seconds. Why?

Since you can't erase colors, many of the puzzle solutions rely on you to simply continue mixing colors into a wall, for example to detach a drone from it. It feels weird to mix all three colors together into black to detach an orange drone from a wall, instead of just being able to erase the color. It feels often unintentional despite being completely intentional.

So the puzzling is mediocre, but sadly, so is the story. The game is clearly trying to do a Portal thing, with a voice guiding you from puzzle to puzzle, with some really cringy dialogue that tries way too hard to do the "quirky corporation that just wants lab rats" thing. Funny enough, you actually do risk your life several times during the game, only for the end to be
the guy essentially offering you a job. What makes you think I want that after almost dying several times, without you really helping me at all? .

We don't really know what this corporation does, we don't know why we are a test subject, we don't know why we are risking our life. The story is paper thin and never captures you, unlike in Portal or even games like The Entropy Centre. You just solve room after room, without ever really knowing why.

So in short, ChromaGun is a very easy game with a few frustrating puzzle outliers, a paper thin story and some sorely missing QOL (if you can describe being able to undo mistakes as QOL, I feel like that is essential). It is also very short and can be finished in 2-3 hours. Overall, I would give this a pass and play some of the many better first person puzzle games - this one needs to be a lot more fleshed out to be fun and engaging.
 
Yarusenai
1,137 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile

Recommandé
3.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 10 septembre 2019
一个做得还可以的解谜游戏。
其实可以很明显地察觉到，在风格和氛围上面，作者极力向《传送门》的感觉靠近。解谜的场所都是一个大公司的实验室，实验室都使用了极简的装潢风格，等等。本作的一个成就也致敬了“蛋糕是个谎言”的梗。不过比起《传送门》里有点病娇感觉的人工智能GLaDOS，本作中一直通过语音给你指示的是一个配音风格并不讨喜的男人。
本作并没有BOSS战，甚至没有《传送门》中在实验室外场景跑路的环节，全是在白花花的实验室里解谜，因此略显单调。剧情也缺乏《传送门》的那种感觉，GLaDOS最起码也是因为实验失败而产生的没什么道德感的自我意识，而语音里的男人真的就是毫无来由地就想杀死你，又是让你踩电又是炸实验设施的，完全是一个想把主角（虽然完全不露脸也没有戏份）当小白鼠的心理变态。你和男人的交流就只有他单方面嘲笑你，并且你还要一直吃瘪到最后，因为这游戏没BOSS战。
不过作为解谜游戏，剧情就算做成这样，也不是重点。那这款游戏的解谜做得如何呢？
游戏的主要解谜机制是一把能打出美术三原色（红黄蓝）子弹的三色枪。用这把枪，可以通过给墙面、地面或游戏中球形的“工用无人机”染色，利用无人机“同色相吸”的原理解谜。游戏中的若干谜题其实还挺有意思的，不过我发觉其中大部分的关卡是无意义的、无创新的重复劳动，或者单纯是将若干个小谜题顺次或并列连接起来。由于游戏中的操作是不可逆的，因此一旦翻车，就得重开，有时我会被这个机制烦到怒退游戏。
不过好在游戏中谜题的难度实际上不高，对操作的要求也基本没有，游戏时长也不长，于是我很轻松地就完成了这个游戏。另外这游戏还有创意工坊，允许玩家自制关卡，虽然因为这游戏完全不火所以关卡没那么多。
所以，喜欢逻辑向解谜游戏的玩家可以试一试这部作品，虽然有缺点，但也说不上是烂作。
 
OldCaptainWZJ

Évaluation publiée le 27 juin 2016
Was soll man dazu sagen... es ist leicht angelehnt an die machart von Portal aber im Leveldesign ganz anders. Es ist mir auch schon oft vorgekommen, dass man oft das Lvl neustarten muss um zu wissen wies läuft da es manchmal zuerst einen Testversuch braucht. Andere Lvl hingegen sind mit sehrviel Feingefühl zu machen da man sonst 100te versuche dafür braucht.
Aber schlussendlich sagt man sich nach jedem Lvl was man geschafft hat ,,Ach ein Lvl geht noch!''. Von daher es erinnert mich sehr an meine Portal Zeit (dich ich gelibt habe) und mit Chromagun auch ein bischen erweitert wird. Meinersteit ist es für den Preis das Spiel aufjedenfall wert und eine Kaufempfehlung für alle Portal Fans!

Non recommandé
3.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 5 juin 2016
This game is alright as a premise, but I think it needed a lot more work before asking for $10+. The controls are pretty clunky, the rooms are all bland and white, and overall it feels like the Alpha/Protoptype of a game that should've had more development put into it. It also tried way too hard to copy Portal's formula; You are given a puzzle-gun to solve puzzles in white rooms while a narrator watches and comments on your actions, all while the facility goes to ♥♥♥♥ as you are testing in it. The puzzles themselves are fairly simple, which may be a consequence of the simplistic premise that floating robots are attracted to color panels that match their own color.

Normally I really love puzzle games, but I just can't recommend this one as is. It feels like an awkward, free mod to a better puzzle game. I just found it far too tedious and I rarely found any satisfaction in solving a puzzle.
 
Cubik

Évaluation publiée le 17 février 2022
Neat little puzzle game using colors and attraction to compose challenges for the player.

Took me 3.5h to finish and then I sweeped up the rest of the achievements, so I'd say it's easy so complete 100% (some puzzles require a bit of speed/reaction). Progressing through the chapters, you get different types of problems to solve and I felt there was the right amount of levels for each chapter. There were only a few rooms that slowed me down. It pays tribute to the big one, nice one devs. ;)

Évaluation publiée le 28 mai 2017
Produit reçu gratuitement

ChromaGun is a revolutional fun complicated puzzle game with one very simple rule - painting/coloring! The main task is to mix three colors into forming others and finding your way out through different obstacles with your chromagun painting tool!
The game also offers an amazing way for it's players to show what their imagination is capable of by intoducing the community map editor allowing people create their own replicas and maps and share them publicly in the ChromaGun steam workshop for other players to download and play!
Beautiful graphics, smooth gameplay, simple rules, extra features allowing players set their imagination free, what more would somebody want from such a well crafted puzzle game!

Vidéo YouTube™: ChromaGun [Watch Menu]

Non recommandé
2.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 21 juillet 2020
So this game isn't awful, it just does enough things wrong that I can't recommend it (even to the people who play every Portal-like game there is, like me), and I'm gonna list them:

  • The first and most annoying: if you fail a step of the level you have to restart it, and the way the game works this is going to happen often. And if I get softlocked because I didn't think it enough everything is fine, it's my fault, but when it happens because I accidentaly chose the wrong color with the mouse wheel, that's enraging.
  • Related to the previous one, at least don't make multi-room levels if there are no checkpoints. One thing is to have to repeat a puzzle from the beginning, another one is to have to redo another one I've already beaten.
  • The not funny narrator, not every first person puzzle game has to be Portal.
  • There are empty rooms sometimes and I still don't know why.
  • The difficulty and quality curve is so weird, you go from very good and difficult levels back to average ones and back again constantly.
  • The last level is probably the worst, kinda sad since the last part of the game had some of the best levels.
  • The achievement for killing 100 bots is pure grind, I don't know why it exists.

Edit: typo
 
jorloru

Évaluation publiée le 12 septembre 2018
Неее ребят, не стоит её брать. Вот серьёзно. Играя в неё ощущение что вы в психбольнице. Вся игра это смена цвета стены. Ну окей. а как вам такое. Ошибся цветом то рестарт уровня, ибо тут удалить цвет нельзя. Про дизайн уровней я промолчу, ибо его просто нету. Про сложность тут писали много раз, что она не стабильна. но такого разброса я увидеть точно не ожидал. Сначала вам дают левел на обьяснение механики. Потом головоломку, где идут тонны исхищрений, а следующий... о, добавте цвет на шарик и уровень сам себя пройдёт... 4 уровня подряд... Как-будто разработчик наобум их ставил. и сам в сие творение не играл. Тоооолько по скидке, и не ждите геймплея аля 1 портал.

3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
4.3 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 30 juin 2019
"It's like Portal but with color mixing." That's how I imagine the pitch to the team went. I thought it was novel. It won't have the physicality of Portal but I've seen some interesting color puzzles before. To the team's credit, the puzzles were fairly interesting, the first time. Each puzzle gets multiple iterations that don't actually make it more interesting just more time consuming. The Portal comparison is inevitable as well as the game tries so hard to be the next Portal. From the testing facility to the omniscient voice that you probably shouldn't trust this game is transparently a clone. That doesn't inherently make it bad, but this game got real boring by the end. The puzzles just drag on and the obstacles never hit a critical density. It's just spiked balls. Spiked balls everywhere. They're slow, easy to dodge, and overall barely register except in numbers or small hallways. The environmental hazards such as the self cleaning panels are more annoying than challenging. Overall it had a few charms, the narrator is entertaining enough and there's a certain catharsis to just spraying the walls whatever colors you want like a painter released from an asylum, but ultimately there are more engaging uses of your time. If you crave some solid first person puzzles, just play Portal or even Myst.
 
Un développeur ou une développeuse a répondu à cette évaluation
Gearhead93
0
3 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Recommandé
5.1 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 26 juillet 2020
Przyjemna gra logiczna na jakieś 3 godzinki. Jednak z Portalem łączy ją chyba tylko kamera i może trochę kolorystyka. Bo tu fabuły w sumie nie ma - masz przetestować sprzęt i tyle. Bawimy w podstawowe mieszanie barw. Czerwony, żółty, niebieski. Malujemy ściany lub kule, otwieramy przejścia i staramy się nie zginąć. To wszystko. A na dodatek niepotrzebnie utrudnione, bo zwykle pomalowanych ścian nie da się wyczyścić, a jeden błąd i poziom jest nie do przejścia. A że nie ma checkpointów, restart. Co może być irytujące... Ale to nadal tylko 3 godziny, więc nie boli aż tak bardzo. W sam raz na jeden wieczór lekkiego główkowania.

This game kind of reminds me of portal, although this one is not as fast paced and not as fluid (engines fault). Also this game does not forgive player his mistakes. If you color atleast one wall/mine with a wrong color, you'll most likely be unable to progress further without a restart and repeating everything you've done before that moment. Grab it on 50% sale to get your monies worth.

Évaluation publiée le 23 mars 2018
Grüßt euch,

bin mir nicht sicher WIE ich an dieses Prachtexemplar eines Spiels gekommen bin aber ich bereue keine Sekunde die ich gespielt hab.
Das Spiel ist so super simpel aufgebaut und dennoch so genial!
Jeder weiß was in der Grundschule passiert ist, wenn man mit den Wassermalfarben in Kunst das panschen angefangen hat? - RICHTIG BRAUN - EVERYONE HATES BROWN!
Es sind teilweise komplexere Rätsel die ihr mit Hilfe eurer RGB-Gun, auch ChromaGun, zu lösen habt.
Klingt im ersten Moment einfach, stellt euch dann trotzdem teilweise vor die große Frage, "WAS ZUM TEUFEL?!"
Die Level bleiben immer überschaubar, für keines braucht man Stunden und ein Tod (ja man kann auch sterben), ist auch nicht so dramatisch wenn man das erste Rätsel im Raum schon gelöst hat.

+Kein Frust
+Ein Spiel zum denken
+Spaßfaktor
+gute Levelgestaltung
+max. Gravity
+100% Erfolg ist machbar ohne Stress
+++ES GIBT DEN KUCHEN WIRKLICH+++

+- Grafik (um ehrlich zu sein die Grafik suckt im vergleich zu aktuellen Titeln aber die ist eh nur Nebensache)

- nix

13€ ist zwar etwas viel, aber derjenige der weiß wo es Gutes zum kleinen Preis gibt, sollte zuschlagen! :)
Klare Kaufempfehlung!

Metatron

Recommandé
3.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 3 février 2020
Review zu ChromaGun

ChromaGun hätte besser sein können.
Portal 1 und 2 scheinen irgendwie ein Subgenre von Puzzlespielen erschaffen zu haben. Puzzle, die ständig in laborhaften Testkammern stattfinden müssen. ChromaGun gehört auch zu dieser Art von Spielen, neben Antichamber und The Turing Test. (und vermutlich noch vielen weiteren, die ich nicht gespielt habe)
Zwar ist dieses Subgenre nichts schlechts, weit davon entfernt, nur ist ChromaGun nicht wirklich die beste Alternative dazu. Es ist recht kurz und sticht, im Gegensatz zur Konkurrenz, nicht wirklich durch irgendetwas hervor. Es ist eines dieser vielen Spiele, die man mal durchspielt, alle Achievements farmt und danach nie wieder anrührt. Zumindest für mich.
Die Idee Farbe an Wände zu schießen, um gewisse Roboter umzulenken ist zwar ganz nett und hier und da kommen ein paar Gimmicks mehr hinzu, die die Puzzlestruktur minimal aufbessern, aber das war´s dann konkret schon.
Merkwürdig war auch, dass das Spiel auch nicht exponenziell schwerer wird, beispielsweise fand ich Kapitel drei deutlich einfacher als den Zweiten. Wobei andere Level, die eigentlich in weit fortgeschritteneren Leveln auftauchten, schlichtweg ein Scherz waren. So dermaßen einfach... Man glaubt es ja nicht.
Gleichzeitig jedoch ist das Spiel unerbittlich dabei einen Fehler zu verzeihen. Denn sollte man nur einen kleinen Fehler machen, muss man den ganzen Level neustarten, weil es keinerlei Möglichkeit gibt, diesen Fehler wieder gut zu machen. Recht idiotisch wie ich finde.
ChromaGun ist nicht perfekt, eignet sich vielleicht noch ganz gut für Puzzleeinsteiger, aber das war es dann auch schon. Wer zudem schnell und einfach Achievements haben will, der kann das Spiel sich ebenso holen.

Kommen wir für die Schnellen unter uns einfach mal zur Pro-Contra-Liste:

Pro:

+ Die Musik fand ich richtig klasse. Habe dabei ständig mit dem Fuß gewippt!
+ Humor des Sprechers war manchmal ganz amüsant
+ Die Funktion des Farbenschießen ist ganz nett
+ Schnelles, und leichtes Spiel, um Achievements zu farmen

Contra:

- Beim Beenden einer Testkammer taucht immer ein kurzer, aber abrupter Ladebildschirm auf und weil das Spiel puzzletechnisch nicht allzu schwer ist, können Ladebildschirme in recht geringer Nachfolge erscheinen, was umso mehr nervt
- Schon beim kleinsten Fehler muss man den Level neustarten, weil es keine Möglichkeit gibt diesen Fehler wieder gut zu machen. Da hätte man gleich einen erzwungenen Neustart einbauen können, sofern man einen Fehler macht. (Allerdings kann ich mir vorstellen, dass dieses Feature für einen Indie-Entwickler zu umständlich wäre)
- Mir gefällt es nicht, dass man über den Testkammern Himmel sehen kann. Decken sehen so auch billig und dünn aus. Besonders merkwürdig ist auch, dass man nach einer Testkammer immer nach oben steigt, aber durch die Decke nie etwas über sich sehen kann, außer dem Himmel

Prontra:

+- Das Intro mit den Firmenlogos ist nicht vorspulbar
+- Grafik könnte hübscher sein. Besonders Texturen an Türen sahen unschön aus. Allerdings waren Reflexionen und dynamische Schatten recht gut anzusehen
+- Einige Passagen in den Untertiteln waren falsch
+- Tests werden, wie man es eigentlich erwarten würde, nicht konstant schwerer
+- Manchmal klang der deutsche Synchronsprecher recht hölzern
+- Es gibt viele überflüssige Elemente in den Testkammern, die vollkommen ohne Nutzen dort platziert worden sind und so die Lösungssuche teils erschweren, weil man doch meinen könnte, dass die gezeigten Objekte doch noch für irgendetwas gut sein könnten. In einem Test habe ich mich sogar gewundert, dass der Test schon vorbei war, weil noch richtig viel anderes Zeug in der Kammer machbar schien, es aber nicht verlangt wurde und nur kosmetischer Natur war... Fatal in einem Puzzlespiel

Brauche ich jetzt nicht noch einmal spielen. Außerdem würde ich bei Interesse auf eine immense Preissenkung warten! Die 12,99€ die das Spiel noch verlangt sind wirklich arg überzogen!

Ich danke fürs Lesen und wünsche sehr viel Spaß beim Spielen! ;-)

 
Vazeyo
1,082 produits enregistrés
0
4 personnes ont trouvé cette évaluation utile
0
Non recommandé
3.9 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 1 janvier 2021
There's something here, but it's never been the Portal game so many people have come looking for.

If you want a puzzle game, go elsewhere, you simply won't find what you're looking for here.

  • Poorly implemented darkness =\= interesting gameplay, rather it leads to confusion and frustration at not being able to see the aspects of the puzzle you're working on.
  • If most of the buttons have lines showing exactly what they activate, they should ALL have said lines.
  • Unintuitive environmental timers shouldn't exist, they do nothing but confuse the player until they finally recognize what the timer is based on.
  • Players will look at a puzzle, assuming that what they are seeing will give them information needed to solve the puzzle. When seeing a painted wall, the player does not immediately assume they have to change the color of said wall in order to draw in an item that is otherwise unseen, that's just poor design. Chapter 8 Floor 3 for anyone wondering.
  • One of the worst things a puzzle game can do is implement a new mechanic or item into a puzzle without ever having explained it. Somehow, Chromagun manages to repeat puzzles increasing in difficulty so mildly that it feels like an extended tutorial for the first few Chapters, yet still introduce the mirror (an item easily circumvented for the remainder of the game) without any tutorial.


On top of that: 100% in <4 hours, with regular breaks prepping for New Years. There's just not much here for the price

Évaluation publiée le 7 novembre 2019
I was hoping this game will be a fun puzzle FPS. But the further I went the worse it became. Some puzzles were missing color lines. Some were VERY strict to timings. In some puzzles you could stuck in a closed room due to not be able to maintain a speed (and there were many rooms you could stuck in). The aim is off (it shots slightly above), it's especially hard to hit those small tiles on the floor across the room.
The story won't develop much. It's just more random puzzles later on.
I liked the narrator, until he became a total jerk. Like If you idle his phase will be - "Stuck? Just do it better!"
Cave Johnson's phrases were more user friendly and funny. I like the voice however. Wish writing were as good.

Évaluation publiée le 8 septembre 2016
Produit reçu gratuitement

For the time I have played and streamed it, I enjoyed this game very much.
(Love on first color! Euh, or should I say colors?)
It has a nice sense of humor in it as the narrator keeps you company.
Somehow it also reminds me of portal in a way, like there giving little winks to that direction. Yet this game is different and on its own.

The puzzles get more challenging as your progress in your game, and I can honestly say I had to push my Z button to reset some a couple of times but eventually figured it out.
There is a way, there is always a way. But not recommended when you are tired, cause some of the puzzles will need your full attention and thought on how to solve it.

So if you like puzzle based games with a relaxing no pressure feature then this is totally the game for you!
And on that note: I also spotted a speed run for the people who do like the pressure and the challenge.

Produit reçu gratuitement

Nice 3D puzzle game, and somehow funny. Something good to stimulate (or burn? :) ) your brain cells.
This game also fits perfectly for whoever likes to do speed runs.
And teleports you back to those child memories where you had to learn which color you would get if you combined yellow + blue. And to remind you that you know you've messed up when you get a very dark color...ohhhh bad droids!!
Runs smoothly and also I didn't manage to find any bugs while playing it, not sure about other players.
Nice alternative to Portal.
+ Steam Achievements

Non recommandé
4.7 h en tout
Évaluation publiée le 9 juillet 2020
Before we start, I think this is a nice puzzle game with potential, but it falls short in many aspects.
  • It tries to be portal. To the point of inserting several references to it. For how short it is, the amount they put in is annoying.
  • Unforgiving puzzles. Mess up and it's back to the start. Now you can pull this off, as seen in Talos Principle. But that game has way more difficulty than this.
  • Flawed game mechanics
    1. No erasing. Which brings up the previous point of starting the room all over again.
    2. Black/brown no real explanation is given why walls and droids in this color don't interact
    3. Late game mechanic: rebounding walls. It's inconsistent, in the introductary puzzle, you clearly have to use that wall to hit another, but it won't work because you didn't angle your initial shot right. It's a game of hit this wall in this exact spot.
    4. Chase sequences. Way too fast for the general pace of the game. Hesitate 5 seconds and you're dead.

This game has a few minor good points though. But not good enough to save this game. It has a colorblind mode based on symbols, not the greatest, but it's something. It also has an editor and workshop for custom levels. It's not very well populated, but could at least bring out more potential than this game gave itself.
 
Gino-Ren

Évaluation publiée le 29 mai 2020
There were a couple clever puzzles in this game that made me smile, but the other 30+ puzzles were so mind-numbing. If you don't care about the puzzles (for whatever reason), and just the story, bad news: the story is more lackluster than that of the original Super Mario Bros., which is to be expected from a game in 1985. This game has no excuse. Lousy optimization makes this game stutter randomly, and this game NEEDS to run nicely at some parts due to super precise placement.

If you're looking for something similar to Portal, this is not it. But if you're willing to look at it at face-value, you might get a graham cracker worth of enjoyment out of it.

3.5/10
